title: A Simple Guide to Turning (Unlinked) Brand Mentions into Links
description: This white-hat link building technique involves finding unlinked mentions for your business on the web and turning them into links.
content: Joshua Hardwick Head of Content @ Ahrefs (or, in plain English, I'm the guy responsible for ensuring that every blog post we publish is EPIC). Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents What if I told you there was an easy way to earn hundreds, possibly even thousands of new backlinks? Youâ€™d jump at the chance, right?Enter: unlinked brand mentions.Unlinked brand mentions are online mentions (citations) of your brandâ€”or anything directly related to your brandâ€”that do not link back to your site.Hereâ€™s one I found for Ahrefs:Unlinked mention for Ahrefs on BloggingTips.comYou can see that despite citing our website, thereâ€™s no link back to us.Hereâ€™s anotherâ€”this time itâ€™s an unlinked mention of Ahrefs Content Explorer:With such mentions, youâ€™re already halfway towards earning a link.You know that the author is familiar with your business because he/she has already mentioned you. So you have the perfect excuse to reach out and, hopefully, convince them to convert that mention into a link.But the question remains: how do you find unlinked brand mentions in the first place?Iâ€™ll show you six simple ways to do so below. But first, letâ€™s talk about the different types of brand mentions.New to link building? Check out ourBeginnerâ€™s guide to link buildingThe Types of (Unlinked) Brand Mentions You Should PursueLetâ€™s say that youâ€™re Apple. Youâ€™d start by looking for unlinked mentions of the word â€œAppleâ€ in tech-related articles.But you can also find unlinked mentions of branded products, services, and slogans, such as:iPad;iPhone;Apple Watch;HomePod;iCloud;Apple Music;AppleCare;â€œThink Differentâ€In short, anything related to your brand that may get mentioned (without a link) is fair game.To illustrate that people do indeed mention such things without linking out, take a look at this article from WhatHifi.com:WhatHifi.comâ€™s review of the Apple Homepod, with no links to Apple.com on the page.Thereâ€™s even scope to turn unlinked mentions of company representatives into links (e.g., someone citing Joshua Hardwick or Tim Soulo but not linking back to Ahrefs in the process).Unlinked mention for â€œTim Souloâ€ on the Storehacks blog.Want proof? I pursued this unlinked mention on Timâ€™s behalf.Hereâ€™s what it looks like now:(Iâ€™ll reveal the exact outreach email I sent to get this link later in the guide.)So before we move on to the tactics, I recommend making a list of any unique products, services, and brand representatives for your business. Here are a few of ours:Ahrefs;Content Explorer;Keywords Explorer / Keyword Explorer;Site Explorer;Tim Soulo;Joshua Hardwick / Josh Hardwick;Dmitry Gerasimenko;Sam Oh;Itâ€™s also worth noting that when pursuing unlinked brand mentions, it pays to prioritize links from high-quality pages.This is because PageRank is calculated at the page-level, not the domain-level.So even if you already have a link from elsewhere on a domain, itâ€™s still totally worth pursuing an unlinked mention on a high-authority (i.e., high UR) page on that same site.Got that? Good.Letâ€™s find some unlinked brand mentions.1. Find Them with Content ExplorerContent Explorer is like a mini search engine within Ahrefs. Itâ€™s powered by our database of almost one billion pages and you can use it to find mentions of anything on the web.Letâ€™s search for â€œAhrefsâ€ and see what we find. Iâ€™ll also exclude results from ahrefs.com by appending my search with -site:ahrefs.com. You can do the same for your domain when searching.Content Explorer > search for brand name (and exclude your domain)Results for â€œAhrefsâ€ in Content Explorer.Thatâ€™s 15K+ mentionsâ€”quite a lot!Letâ€™s add some filters to restrict the results to English pages that live on sites with a Domain Rating (DR) of 30 or more. Iâ€™ll also add an organic traffic filter to get rid of pages with, say, less than 50 organic visits per month. Like I said earlier, thereâ€™s no point in pursuing unlinked mentions on low-quality pages.Now weâ€™re down to 558 results, which weâ€™ll export to CSV.Sidenote. You can also add filters for word count, organic traffic, and a bunch of other attributes. These are useful if you see a particularly high number of results. For example, a search for â€œNike,â€ for example, kicks back nearly 250K resultsâ€”that definitely needs some heavy filtering! Want to pursue links from new referring domains instead?The primary aim here is to build links from unique pages that donâ€™t link to you.But if youâ€™re interested in finding and pursuing link opportunities from new ref.domains (which Google loves), you can use the â€œhighlight unlinked mentionsâ€ feature in Content Explorer.This will highlight all the sites that have never linked to you.Unlinked mention of Ahrefs on quickbooks.intuit.com.Next upâ€”export the results. Make sure the â€œOnly highlighted unlinked domainsâ€ checkbox is ticked. This will ensure that only the unlinked domains are exported.But not all of these pages contain unlinked mentions. Many of them already link to us. So we need a way to run through these pages and find only the unlinked mentions.Here are three tools you can use to do this:Screaming Frog SEO Spider;Free Link Checker Tool (by Scrapebox);Buzzstream (read their link monitoring tutorial)Scrapebox is probably the best tool for this task, but it only works on Windows and I use a Mac. Buzzstream is another good option but it isnâ€™t the cheapestâ€”it also isnâ€™t really made for this purpose. So letâ€™s use Screaming Frogâ€™s custom search feature.Hereâ€™s a video demonstrating exactly how to do this (keep reading for the written walkthrough):https://youtu.be/S0ZZ8T_AkyA?t=2m51sScreaming Frog > Configuration > Custom > SearchWeâ€™ll use the â€œDoes not containâ€ search and enter the Regex below.<a [^>]*\bhref\s*=\s*"([^"]*ahrefs.com[^"]*)Donâ€™t worry, this isnâ€™t as scary as it looks. You donâ€™t need to understand this regex code.If you want to follow along, just replace ahrefs.com with your own domain (minus the https://www.). Hereâ€™s how it would look for both google.com and theseoproject.org:<a [^>]*\bhref\s*=\s*"([^"]*google.com[^"]*)<a [^>]*\bhref\s*=\s*"([^"]*theseoproject.org[^"]*)Hereâ€™s what it should look like in Screaming Frog:Sidenote. I also recommend unchecking everything under the â€œBasicâ€ tab within the Spider Configuration (Configuration > Spider) and limiting the crawl depth to 0 on the â€œLimitsâ€ tab. It will take ages to run if you donâ€™t do this.Now letâ€™s copy-paste the Content URLs (from the Content Explorer export) into Screaming Frog and run it.Finally, weâ€™ll go to the â€œCustomâ€ tab and select the â€œDoes not containâ€ filter we set from the drop-down. This will show us all the pages that donâ€™t link to us (i.e., those containing unlinked mentions).Out of the 558 URLs we checked, 164 contained unlinked mentionsâ€”roughly 29%!Itâ€™s now a case of working down the list, opening each of the URLs and looking for good contenders for this type of link building.Hereâ€™s an unlinked mention that would be fantastic to turn into a link:Letâ€™s try to do this, shall we?SUCCESS.I donâ€™t deserve the credit this time, though; Helen got this one.PRO TIPDo you have a lot of pages to manually sift through? Make a copy of this Google Sheet and:Copy-paste your entire Content Explorer export into the tab labelled â€œContent Explorerâ€;Copy-paste your entire Screaming Frog export into the tab labelled â€œSFâ€Then go to the â€œResultsâ€ tab. You will see all unlinked mentions sorted by estimated organic traffic to the pageâ€”this will help with prioritising the manual checks.You can also order by Domain Rating (DR). Just use the drop-down.NOTE. Not sure how the spreadsheet works? See an example here.With opportunities like this, it pays to take action right away. So reach out to the site owner and kindly request the addition of a link. Check out this guide if you need help finding their email address.Rinse and repeat this exact process for the other â€œbrandedâ€ terms on your list.2. Find Them With a Google SearchGoogle offers another way to find brand mentions. Itâ€™s just less convenient than Content Explorer as itâ€™s harder to extract the results.Letâ€™s search for â€œAhrefsâ€ and exclude results from ahrefs.com using the same search operator as before. Iâ€™ll also exclude results from well-known social media sites, as these arenâ€™t useful.Hereâ€™s my search:intext:ahrefs -ahrefs.com -twitter.com -facebook.com -pinterest.com -youtube.comThis kicks back 500K+ results.But hereâ€™s the problem: thereâ€™s no way we can extract all these results from Google.Even if you set the number of search results you see per page to 100 (you can do this in your Google settings), Google will never show more than 5 pages of resultsâ€”so 500.This is the case even if the search supposedly returns thousands or millions of results.quick hackUse Googleâ€™s inbuilt filter to restrict results to a certain date range.For example, if we filter the search above to show only results from the past 24 hours, the number of search results drops from 400K+ to <500.If you really wanted to, you could do this for many different date ranges, extract the results from each search (see below to learn how), then combine all of them in one spreadsheet.Or, yâ€™know, if you value your time at all, just use Content Explorer. ğŸ˜‰Next, scrape the results.I recommend using Chris Ainsworthâ€™s scraper for this. Make sure Google is set to show 100 results at a time and use Chrisâ€™s extension to scrape all results from the page. Rinse and repeat for all viewable pages of results (up to 5).Paste the results into a spreadsheet.Sidenote. Got a lot of brand-related terms to scrape? You can easily automate the boring scraping process by employing the help of a VAâ€”theyâ€™re pretty cheap on places like UpWork. Alternatively, use an automated SERP scraping tool like Citation Labs Link Prospector to do the heavy-lifting.We now have a list of pages that mention us. But we have no clue which (if any) of these pages link back to us. This is the same problem we faced after exporting brand mentions from Content Explorer.To fix this, weâ€™ll employ the same solution as before: check for links back to our site on each page using Screaming Frog SEO Spider, the Free Link Checker Tool (by Scrapebox), or Buzzstream.I did this for 530 pages I scraped from Google. 158 had linked mentions. Thatâ€™s ~30%.But how high-quality are these pages? I mean, do we even want a link from them?Letâ€™s copy these URLs into Ahrefs Batch Analysis tool to pull some additional metrics. Then weâ€™ll sort by URL Rating (UR).Sidenote. Do you have a ton of unlinked mentions to pull metrics for? Try using the Ahrefs API connection in Screaming Frog to pull stats for thousands of pages at once.Looking to pursue links from new referring domains?I recommend pursuing page-level unlinked mentions rather than domain-level links.But if you do want to find â€œunlinked domainsâ€ and go after links from new ref.domains, you can do so easily with a bit of spreadsheet magic.Make a copy of this Google Sheet. Enter your domain (without the http or www) in the cell labelled â€œYOUR DOMAIN HEREâ€ on the â€œSettingsâ€ tab.Next, copy-paste the scraped pages from Google into the tab labelled â€œGoogle Scrape,â€ then do a full export of Referring Domains for your domain from Ahrefs Site Explorer.Site Explorer > yourdomain.com > Referring Domains > ExportPaste the exported data from Ahrefs into the tab marked â€œAHREFS EXPORT.â€Now go back to the â€œGoogle Scrapeâ€ tab and youâ€™ll see that all unlinked domains are highlighted and marked.NOTE. Not sure how to use the spreadsheet? See an example here.Hereâ€™s an unlinked mention in an article on SEJ:According to the stats pulled using Ahrefs Batch Analysis tool, it doesnâ€™t get much traffic. But it does have a URL Rating (UR) of 30 and lives on a site with a Domain Rating (DR) of 88.This is definitely an unlinked mention worth pursuing!Editorâ€™s NoteWe did pursue this link, but had no joy. ğŸ™I thought we should mention this for transparency. You wonâ€™t have a 100% success rate with any link building tactic. Pursuing unlinked mentions is no different.Tim SouloHead of Marketing and Product Strategy3. Find Them By Reverse-Engineering Your Twitter ProfilePeople will sometimes link to your Twitter profile instead of your actual website, often by accident.Hereâ€™s a good example:Just looks like theyâ€™re linking to a few popular keyword research tools, right?A closer inspection of these links reveals that while theyâ€™re linking to the homepages of Ubersuggest and SEMRush, the Ahrefs link actually points to our Twitter.Here are a few reasons this might happen:Theyâ€™re scared of Google: SEO misinformation has spread and theyâ€™re worried that Google will penalise them for linking out to too many external sites. NOTE.They donâ€™t want to link to your particular site: Similar reasons as above but, this time, itâ€™s because they think your site is low-quality (e.g., low-DR).Genuine mistake: Iâ€™m not sure how many of you use Google Docs when writing blog posts, but it gives link suggestions based on your highlighted anchor text. Itâ€™s easy to choose the wrong link sometimesâ€”I know Iâ€™ve accidentally added links to inferior, similarly named tools like Keywords Explorer before.In this case, Iâ€™d guess the reason was #3.But how did I find this anyway?Simple. I just threw the Ahrefsâ€™ Twitter handle (twitter.com/ahrefs) into Ahrefs Site Explorer and used the Backlinks report.Site Explorer > enter your Twitter URL > BacklinksBacklinks report in Ahrefs Site ExplorerI then exported the report before copy-pasting the Referring page URLs into Screaming Frog to check for unlinked mentions.Sidenote. I deleted any referring pages from ahrefs.com before doing so.Out of the 262 pages I checked, 142 didnâ€™t link back to ahrefs.comâ€”thatâ€™s ~54%.Next, I used Ahrefs Batch Analysis tool to sort the pages by UR. Thatâ€™s what led me to discover the unlinked mention (from Infobunny) that I showed you earlier.Again, if you only want to pursue links from new referring domainsâ€¦Export the Backlinks report from Ahrefs Site Explorer and copy-paste all referring pages into column A on the â€œTwitterâ€ tab in your Google Sheet. It will then highlight any â€œunlinked domainsâ€.Note: I filtered out any links from ahrefs.com in the screenshot above. To do this, just use the filter on column B.If you spot any pages linking to your Twitter profile when a straight domain link would make more sense, reach out and try to swap the link.Editorâ€™s NoteThese next two tactics blur the line between â€œunlinked mentionsâ€ and â€œlink reclamation.â€ But ultimately, I think theyâ€™re a better fit for this post, since neither strategy involves reclaiming a lost link.Tim SouloHead of Marketing and Product Strategy4. Find Domain Name MisspellingsHereâ€™s an article that links to us and one of our competitors:Letâ€™s check the source code.Do you see the problem? Theyâ€™ve accidentally linked to aherfs.com instead of ahrefs.comâ€”a surprisingly common mistake.These are some of the quickest wins when it comes to link-building.Nine times out of 10, authors of such posts havenâ€™t realised their mistake. If you let them know, theyâ€™ll usually be more than happy swap out the link for the correct one.Want proof? Hereâ€™s what the link looks like in that very article now:All I had to do was to send a quick â€œheads up!â€ email to the site owner.Hereâ€™s how to find misspelled links quickly and easily:Enter your domain into this domain typo generator, then hit â€œgenerate typos.â€Itâ€™ll kick back something like this:Hit â€œCopy to clipboardâ€ and paste the entire list into Ahrefs Batch Analysis tool. Sort by Referring Domains (desc).Stats for misspelled versions of ahrefs.com sorted by Referring domains, via Ahrefs Batch Analysis toolSidenote. Make sure to use the *.domain/* mode.You can see that many of the misspelled versions of ahrefs.com have a ton of backlinks.Next step: take a look at the backlink profiles for any of the domains with at least one referring domain. Use the Backlinks report in Site Explorer for this.Site Explorer > enter misspelled domain > BacklinksLooking at the Backlinks report for ahref.com, it quickly becomes apparent that most of the links arenâ€™t the result of accidental misspellings. Thatâ€™s because ahref.com is a website in itâ€™s own right.Backlinks report for ahref.com, via Ahrefs Site ExplorerSidenote. This is something to be aware of. You can usually tell when a link is intended for your own site or another. Still, there are a few links in here that clearly should point to ahrefs.com, such as this one that points to aherfs.com:(Yes, this is same the article I successfully claimed the link from above.)I found this by searching the Backlinks report for the correct spelling of our brand name (Ahrefs).This filters for any links that use the correct anchor text but have the wrong linkâ€”these are likely to be misspelled links intended for your domain.5. Find Stolen Images With Googleâ€™s Reverse Image SearchPeople will occasionally steal and embed your images on their site without proper attribution (i.e., a link back to your site - the original source).Hereâ€™s an image from WaitButWhy.com embedded on Olaeconomics.com:Having looked at the source code. I donâ€™t see an attribution link.If I was Tim Urbanâ€”the guy behind WaitButWhy.comâ€”I may want to reach out to the owner of this site and request a link.But I know what youâ€™re wondering:â€œHow did you find this unlinked image embed in the first place?â€I did a reverse image search in Google.If youâ€™re using Chrome, this is as easy as right-clicking on the image you want to search for, and hitting â€œSearch Google for Image.â€Sidenote. If you donâ€™t see this option when right-clicking an image, try installing this Chrome extension.Infographics, GIFs, illustrations, and logos are the best contenders for this tactic, as these are the things people usually â€œaccidentallyâ€ embed without attribution.So find an image on your site that you feel is likely to get stolen, then follow the process above.You should see search results like this:Google reverse image search results for the image from waitbutwhy.comYou can use Chris Ainsworthâ€™s Chrome extension to scrape these. (Yes, it works with Image results too.) Then you can follow the same technique as before: use a tool like Screaming Frog to check which of these pages do not link back to you. If you have a lot and want to prioritise, pull in some Ahrefs metrics using our Batch Analysis tool or the Ahrefs API connection in Screaming Frog.For those seeking links from new ref.domainsâ€¦Just copy-paste these extracted results into the â€œReverse imageâ€ tab in your Google Sheet. It will once again highlight any unlinked domains.Googleâ€™s reverse image search isnâ€™t the only tool you can use to find unlinked image embedsâ€”thereâ€™s also Tineye.This usually finds more results than Google, in my experience.However, thereâ€™s no export button on the results, although they do have an API (paid).Thereâ€™s also Tineye Alertsâ€”a premium service ($300+/month)6. Keep an Eye on New Unlinked (Brand) Mentions With Ahrefs AlertsYou should now have a decent list of unlinked mentions to pursue.But hereâ€™s the thing: new unlinked mentions appear all the time, especially if youâ€™re a well-known or semi well-known brand.To illustrate, I used Content Explorer to find only English mentions for â€œnikeâ€ from the past week. I also filtered to show only pages with at least 50 monthly organic visits, living on DR30+ sites.In total, there were 393 pages, of which 329 didnâ€™t link back to nike.comâ€”thatâ€™s ~84%.Unlinked mentions for â€œnikeâ€ from the past 7 days, via Ahrefs Content ExplorerYou can bet that thereâ€™ll be a similar amount of new unlinked mentions next week.Now, you could follow the process above every couple of months to find new unlinked mentions, then tackle them as necessary. But wouldnâ€™t it be better if you could them instantly, without lifting a finger?Yes, it wouldâ€¦ which brings us to Ahrefs Alerts.Just set up a mention alert for your brand name (and other branded terms) and Ahrefs will keep you posted about new brand mentions on the web.Alerts > Mentions > New AlertDonâ€™t forget to exclude your own domain and set your notification interval (I recommend weekly).Try using advanced operatorsDid you know that you can also use advanced operators here?For example, you can use the OR operator to set up a single alert for your brand name AND common misspellings.You could even do the same for multiple branded productsâ€”iMac, iPad, iPhone, Macintosh, Apple Watch, etc.NOTE. Just make sure the OR is capitalized. Otherwise it wonâ€™t work.Youâ€™ll now get real-time/daily/weekly alerts about new brand mentions, which helps you to respond to any unlinked mentions quickly.This is important because authors are often more likely to add your link if you reach out soon after they publish the post.But hereâ€™s an important point:This alert includes all mentions. It wonâ€™t tell you whether the page/domain is linking to you or not. So youâ€™ll still have to open each page to manually verify if the link is there.If that sounds tedious or boring, donâ€™t think of it as pure SEO tactic. The practice of monitoring your online mentions has many applications from reputation management to influencer marketing. In other words, you want to keep an eye on what people say about you online.BONUS: Outreach AdviceNow that you have a decent list of opportunities, itâ€™s time to do some outreach and convert those unlinked mentions into links.Here are a few resources to help with this:Further readingI Just Deleted Your Outreach Email Without Reading. And NO, I Donâ€™t Feel Sorry. (Evergreen)How We Use Blogger Outreach To Promote Content And Build LinksBuzzStream Data: The Outperforming Outreach Tactics We Learned From Analyzing 12,000 CampaignsBut as this is a specific â€œtypeâ€ of outreach, here are a few additional tips that should serve you well:DONâ€™T be pushy: Does the current unlinked mention actually make sense within the context of the article? Does the site already link to you a bazillion times on other pages? Then LEAVE IT. Pick your targets wisely and donâ€™t be pushyâ€”itâ€™s not worth it.DONâ€™T request links unless they actually add value: Letâ€™s say thereâ€™s an unlinked mention for Coca Cola in an article entitled, â€œWhy Coca Cola and Pepsi Are Bad For Your Teeth.â€ Do you really think converting that unlinked mention to a link will serve any purpose for the readers of that post? Probably not, so donâ€™t bother pursuing such links.DO offer additional value: Did you spot another mistake (e.g., spelling/grammatical errors, broken links, etc.) on the page from which youâ€™re trying get a link? Tell the author about such things in your outreach email. Not only is this genuinely helpful, but itâ€™ll also increase their willingness to go back and edit the post. At that point, they may as well add your link, right? ğŸ˜‰In other words, use your common sense and donâ€™t blindly pursue every opportunity you come across. Pick your battles wisely and try not to annoy people.Oh, and as promised, hereâ€™s the outreach email I used to convert the unlinked mention on storehacks.com to a linked mention:Pretty simple, right?I explain why the link would add value and be useful for storehacks.com readers (i.e., because it helps them find Ahrefs). And I offer some additional value by suggesting a small, appropriate update to the post title.Just donâ€™t copy this email word for word. Come up with your own template and personalise it for each site you reach out to.Final ThoughtsConverting unlinked mentions to links is an ongoing process, as new opportunities pop up all the time. This is especially true for well-known brands.So I recommend that you follow the process laid out above on a regular/semi-regular basis.And donâ€™t forget that you can use a tool like Ahrefs Alerts to stay on top of new potentially, unlinked mentions without lifting a finger.For more link building strategies that donâ€™t require content, read this post.
